og_title: Bus driver critically injured in crash with van on Regional Road
og_subtitle: The accident caused long tailbacks on Monday
og_content: A bus driver, 37, was critically injured in a collision with a van on the Regional Road on Monday morning.  The accident happened at 10.30am on a southbound lane just after the tunnels. The bus, which was not carrying passengers, ended up straddling the centre strip and debris was spread over a wide area, causing the closure of busy traffic lanes. An eyewitness said she saw the bus driver lying on the road with blood on his head. The van was driven by a 39-year-old woman from Naxxar who was not seriously hurt.
og_top_image_caption: The van damaged in the Regional Road accident. Photo Johnathan Borg.

og_content: A bus driver, 37, was critically injured in a collision with a van on the Regional Road on Monday morning.  The accident happened at 10.30am on a southbound lane just after the tunnels. og_top_image_caption: The van damaged in the Regional Road accident. Photo Johnathan Borg.

og_title: Watch: Road Safety Bureau proposals to be unveiled after year-long delay
og_subtitle: Minister says legislative changes will be needed
og_content: The Transport Ministry is set to present its ideas for the establishment of a road safety bureau in the coming weeks, more than a year after the bureau was meant to be operational. The Transport Safety Investigative Commission will be tasked to investigate the causes of serious road accidents.  Minister Chris Bonett said on Monday that his ministry was holding talks with the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of Home Affairs on the setting up of the bureau. “In the coming weeks, we will present the first ideas on the bureau,” Bonett said when questioned, saying that changes to laws will be required.    At present, magisterial inquiries and police investigations are the only tools available for the investigation of road accidents in Malta. Their findings typically remain confidential, which has drawn criticism from various quarters. Victims’ families, insurers, and medical associations have condemned the delay in establishing the bureau, describing it as symptomatic of road safety being sidelined. During the press conference, Bonett also urged drivers to observe traffic rules and treat one another with respect. “We must ensure that such bureaus and road safety councils are needed as little as possible,” he said.
og_top_image_caption: Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

og_title: Drivers fume as large pothole leaves trail of flat tyres in Iklin
og_subtitle: Heavy rainfall carves out potholes just off Birkirkara bypass
og_content: More than a dozen cars sustained flat tyres on Friday afternoon after heavy rains carved out a massive pothole on a busy road. Frustrated motorists contacted Times of Malta to report vehicle damage as they drove through Triq il-Għargħur in Iklin, corner with Triq Dun Karm, near the Scan outlet. “It’s mayhem here. Drivers are getting out of their cars, furious,” one motorist said, describing the chaotic scene. One driver counted at least 12 cars sustaining flat tyres though he was sure others had simply driven on not realising the damage. Despite calls to the authorities to repair the pothole or divert traffic, no action had been taken by 4.30pm, leaving hundreds of drivers to navigate the treacherous road or rely on sheer luck.  A motorist claimed the pothole had been present for weeks, but Friday’s heavy rain worsened the damage, while the flowing water concealed the hazard from drivers. Malta was battered by gale-force winds earlier in the day before a sudden downpour caused widespread flooding, worsening road conditions.
og_top_image_caption: One of the cars was towed away.

og_title: Here are the 10 Maltese roads where you’re most likely to get a fine from TM
og_subtitle: Chris Bonett answers a parliamentary question put forward by Jerome Caruana Cilia
og_content: The road from the Valletta World War II monument to Castille is the street that saw the most traffic fines being issued by Transport Malta in the first quarter of last year. The list does not include traffic fines issued by police and LESA. Data provided to parliament by Transport Minister Chris Bonett shows that 102 contraventions were given out on Triq Girolamo Cassar in January, February, and March, 2024. The 100 infringements issued on a street in the Corradino Industrial Estate, It-Telgħa ta’ Ras Ħanżir, made it the second street where most tickets were issued.  Ninety-one tickets were handed out at the airport, the data shows. Bonett was answering a parliamentary question put forward by PN MP Jerome Caruana Cilia, who asked for the 10 roads in Malta where the most citations were issued during the first three months of 2024. A spokesperson for the ministry clarified the data presented reflects fines issued solely by Transport Malta. Also featuring in the list is Triq Giuseppe Garibaldi – Marsa (79), Triq il-Mitjar – Luqa (73), Triq San Pawl – Valletta (62), Coast Road – Naxxar (56), Ħemsija – Rabat (51), Triq Elija Zammit – St Julian’s (46), Triq il-Buqana – Rabat (43).
og_top_image_caption: The data provided to parliament.

og_title: Bonett reverses decision to raise age requirement for vintage cars
og_subtitle: 'I admit we were a bit hasty with the measure', says the transport minister
og_content: Updated 9.30pm Chris Bonett has reversed his decision to raise the age requirement for cars to be considered 'vintage'. Speaking in a Times Talk episode that will be released next week, the Transport Minister said that after consulting with classic car enthusiasts he realised he "may have jumped the gun" when he announced the measure. "I admit we were a bit hasty with that measure. I don't mind admitting that, and I don't think it's a sign of weakness to admit a mistake. Rather, it shows you're serious," he said. "I still agree with the measure but I may have jumped the gun when I announced it. We want to protect the hobby of vintage cars while making sure nobody abuses the system." Currently, cars that are older than 30 years are exempted from annual licence fees and must only pay an annual €8 administrative fee, provided the vehicle does not exceed 3,000 kilometres per year. Vintage vehicles are marked on Maltese roads with a black number plate. But the authorities observed that some drivers were passing off their old cars as 'vintage', managing to pay very low licence fees for a car they use every day and which is not a classic car at all. Moreover, 'hundreds' of old, second-hand vehicles are being imported every year and registered as vintage cars but used as ordinary cars for every day transportation by abusing the loophole in the system. Last week, as part of a raft of measures aimed at tackling Malta's chronic traffic congestion, Bonett announced the government would curb vintage car abuse by introducing a measure that stipulates that vehicles must be 35 years old to qualify for a black number plate and that they will be subject to inspections. But during the filming of Times Talk on Thursday, Bonett told Times of Malta he will amend that measure and that he takes full responsibility for the oversight. "We're not after people's hobbies," he said. "We only need to make sure that the fees for classic car enthusiasts are not abused by people who want to keep their junk cars on the road." Later on Thursday the Minister said on Facebook that there was an agreement on the decision following a meeting with the Maltese Vintage Vehicle Federation.  "The purpose of the meeting was to understand where we want to go as a Government, to remove from our roads ordinary cars that are being used under the guise of being 'vintage' and abusing the system, while protecting those who invest in truly classic cars," he wrote. "We agreed on everything, and in the coming weeks, after the necessary legal work is done, we will announce how the reform, which everyone agrees we need, will work. "What I can anticipate from now is that we are satisfied that we can achieve our goal without raising the car age requirement from 30 to 35 years. In fact, we will introduce measures that will strengthen this hobby." Unplanned measures - PN One hour after the Nationalist Party held a press conference in Msida on Thursday criticising the government's proposals, transport minister Chris Bonett admitted he had changed his mind about the vintage car scheme, the Opposition said. In a statement, the PN said this "further confirmed just how Saturday's anouncement was unplanned and without consultation." "Bonett reversed this measure following the pressure made by the Opposition in the last days in parliament and outside," the PN said.
og_top_image_caption: Times Talk with Chris Bonett will be released next week. Photo: Karl Andrew Micallef

og_title: Traffic disruptions in St Julian's, Sliema amid ongoing cable works
og_subtitle: Part of Ċensu Tabone Street closed until May 16
og_content: A stretch of Ċensu Tabone Street, from St Julian’s to Sliema, has been closed to traffic due to underground cabling works, sparking traffic disruptions in the area. The works are being carried out by Enemalta to strengthen the electricity distribution system.  Work began on a section of Tower Road in Sliema on Monday. Traffic coming from the direction of St Julian’s is being diverted through Triq Anglu Mikiel Borg, although vehicles coming from Sliema are not affected. A motorist described the situation on Monday night and Tuesday morning as “chaotic,” saying traffic from St Julian’s to Sliema, from the Spinola Love Sign all the way through Regional Road, was spilling out into all possible exits. A lot of the traffic chaos appears to be centred near the Neptunes Waterpolo pitch.  By noon on Tuesday, however, traffic in the area had begun to ease and had become more localised.
og_top_image_caption: It's no entry from the road next to Love Monument in Spinola.

og_title: Widely-respected diver Dione Galdes dies after Sunday accident
og_subtitle: 'His passion for diving was matched only by his dedication to sharing it with others'
og_content: A 59-year-old diver has succumbed to injuries he suffered in an accident in Cirkewwa early on Sunday. The police confirmed his death on Tuesday morning at Mater Dei Hospital. Dione Galdes an experienced diving instructor from Iklin, was widely respected in the diving community.  "Dione was not only a skilled diving instructor but also a trusted mentor, a generous advisor, and a true companion to all who had the privilege of knowing him," said Andrew P Zammit chairman, Calypso Subaqua Club in a Facebook tribute. "His calm, approachable nature made him easy to work with, and his passion for diving was matched only by his dedication to sharing it with others." He said that over the years Dione gave tirelessly of his time and expertise—supporting the club with teaching, technical guidance, and unwavering friendship. "Many of us took our first underwater breaths under his care, and countless divers carry a part of his legacy in their training and love for the sport. His absence leaves a deep void in our community, but his spirit, his laughter, and his wisdom will remain with us always." Magistrate Ian Farrugia is leading an investigation.
og_top_image_caption: Photo: Facebook/Calypso Sub-Aqua Club.

og_title: 1,000 requests for emergency ambulances in five days
og_subtitle: Emergency doctor Michael Spiteri calls on people to be more sensitive and avoid filming or photographing accidents
og_content: The emergency services were called to assist 1,000 people over five days with cases ranging from fatal and life-threatening accidents to people who consumed too much alcohol, emergency doctor Michael Spiteri has said. Speaking on TVM news, Spiteri noted that between Thursday and Monday, the emergency ambulance service attended over 200 cases daily. “Half of the 1,000 calls for assistance included people with serious problems [who did not need immediate medical assistance for survival], and 10% of them were in a critical situation in which, a few minutes could make a difference between life and death”, he said. Spiteri appealed to people who happened to be passing near an accident, to keep away from the site in order not to disrupt the emergency doctors. He called for more sensitivity and for people not to film or photograph accidents, saying this caused psychological damage to patients and their relatives. Over the past days, there were five fatalities on the road. On Saturday, a 27-year-old motorcyclist — Bulgarian Tenyo Kosev — was killed when his bike was involved in a crash with a BMW in Pembroke in the early hours of the morning. The following day, a woman died in a head-on crash in Fgura that also involved former president George Abela and his wife. A motorcyclist died in Pietà a few hours later. And on Sunday, evening mother-of-four, Mildred Azzopardi, died when she was trapped between two cars in a crash. A 23-year-old soldier has been charged with involuntary homicide for her death. On Tuesday, 63-year-old Tallinja driving instructor Karmenu Muscat, died after a bus rolled back on him at the Floriana Park and Ride facility at around 1.45 pm.
og_top_image_caption: The emergency services received 1,000 calls in five days. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

og_title: Eight-year-old and two motorcyclists seriously injured in two traffic accidents
og_subtitle: The accidents took place in Naxxar and Żabbar
og_content: Two motorcycle drivers and an eight-year-old boy were taken to hospital yesterday with serious injuries following traffic accidents in Naxxar and Żabbar. The first accident occurred at around 11.30 am, when a Nooma Bravo GLE motorbike driven by a 48-year-old Bulgarian resident of St. Paul’s Bay was involved in a collision with a Hyundai I10 driven by a 60-year-old Spaniard on Triq is-Salina in Naxxar. The second accident took place around an hour later on Triq Bormla in Żabbar, when a Fiat Scudo driven by a 23-year-old man from Kirkop and a Honda NSS motorbike driven by a 45-year-old man from Żabbar, with an eight-year-old boy riding as passenger, collided. All those involved were treated at the scene, with both motorcycle drivers and the eight-year-old boy taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where their injuries were certified as serious. Police investigations are ongoing.
og_top_image_caption: Two motorcyclists and an eight-year-old boy were taken to hospital with serious injuries. File photo.

og_title: MHRA backs calls for random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol
og_subtitle: Hotel and restaurant lobby says 'time for action is now'
og_content: The Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association (MHRA) has come out in favour of revising laws to allow police to conduct random roadside drug and alcohol checks.  Calls for a change in legislation have been amplified in recent weeks following a spate of fatal or serious crashes involving alcohol or drug-impaired drivers.  Currently, police can only breathalyse drivers if they have a "reasonable suspicion" that drivers are under the influence. Police are only equipped with alcohol breathalysers.  In a statement published on Tuesday, MHRA said it backed a call by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin, who called for random testing of motorists in a Times of Malta opinion piece published on Monday.  Joslin warned MPs that if they did not revise the law, they would have to bear moral responsibility for any ensuing road deaths in which drugs or alcohol are involved.  The MHRA called for the government and MPs to heed Joslin's call, highlighting how the "time for action is now". "MHRA stresses that for a country like Malta, where tourism is a cornerstone of the economy, safety is not opitional, it is essential," the statement read. The Insurance Association Malta has also backed the doctor's call for random drug and alcohol testing of motorists.  "A safe environment on our roads is just as important as the quality of our hotels, restaurants, and attractions. Tourists choose destinations where they can enjoy themselves with peace of mind, and residents deserve the same assurance every day." MHRA said that random roadside testing would send a clear message that the country people can visit confidently and enjoy responsibly.  "Such measures do not restrict enjoyment, they raise the standard of living and hospitality for everyone."  The past few weeks have seen a string of road accidents and deaths linked to drink-driving.  On Monday, a woman involved in a collision that left a motorcyclist critically injured on Sunday was six times over the legal alcohol limit at the time.  In another recent case, a 42-year-old food courier from Nepal was killed when his motorcycle was hit by a Maserati car in Santa Venera. A 17-year-old driver was later charged after fleeing the scene, and pleaded not guilty to driving under the influence.  Mother-of-four Mildred Azzopardi was killed when she was caught between two cars after a car driven by a soldier crashed into a stationary vehicle in Valletta. The driver, Benjamin Chetcuti, is charged with involuntary homicide, driving under the influence and grievously injuring another man through negligence.
og_top_image_caption: Hoteliers back doctors call for random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol following a spike in road accidents linked to driving under the influence. Photo: Matthew Mirabelli

og_title: Catering establishments join calls for random substance testing
og_subtitle: Caterers' association joins hotels and insurers in backing random testing
og_content: The Association of Catering Establishments (ACE) has joined a chorus of voices calling for the introduction of random drug and alcohol tests of motorists.   Currently, police can only breathalyse drivers if they have "reasonable suspicion" that drivers are under the influence. Police are only equipped with alcohol breathalysers.  Calls for a change in legislation have been amplified in recent weeks following a series of fatal or serious crashes involving alcohol or drug-impaired drivers.   The association referred to “alarming” data compiled in 2022 by the Insurance Association Malta, which is also in favour of random testing, that revealed breathalyser tests were only used in around three per cent of serious traffic accidents.  “This data clearly highlights the need for a revision in the current legislation,” ACE said.  The organisation referred to a recent opinion piece published in Times of Malta by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin, who wrote that members of parliament would bear moral responsibility for future road deaths involving drugs and alcohol should the law remain unchanged. ACE added that it also supported calls by Caritas for strict ID card checks in supermarkets, groceries and catering establishments.  “Above all, ACE also supports the recent call for a public education campaign aimed at clarifying the risks associated with alcohol consumption and driving to remind the public that any amount of alcohol in the bloodstream can impair their ability to drive safely.”  The association stressed that road safety is a collective effort which calls on government, legislators, political parties, civil society and individuals to ensure safer roads, better enforcement and fewer deaths.  On Monday, the Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association also came out in support of revising laws to allow police to conduct random substance testing.  "MHRA stresses that for a country like Malta, where tourism is a cornerstone of the economy, safety is not optional; it is essential," the association said.  In a recent inquiry into the death of a motorcyclist who was found to have cocaine in his system, Magistrate Joe Mifsud endorsed a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.   Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers.
og_top_image_caption: Currently, police can only administer a breathalyser test if they have reasonable suspicion that a motorist is intoxicated. Photo: Shutterstock.

og_title: Over a day later, police still searching for driver who fled Birkirkara crash
og_subtitle: The Friday morning accident left a motorcyclist with serious injuries
og_content: Over 24 hours after a collision between a motorcycle and a car left a biker with serious injuries, police are still looking for the car driver who fled the scene of the accident. A 57-year-old man from Msida, who was riding a Honda motorbike, was involved in a collision with a Nissan March at 5.30am on Friday on Sir Anthony Mamo Street in Birkirkara. Police had said that a 25-year old woman, who is now understood to have been the passenger in the Nissan, was taken to hospital in a state of shock. She was otherwise uninjured. However, the male driver of the Nissan allegedly fled the scene of the accident. On Saturday afternoon, police confirmed they are still looking for the man as investigations into the accident continue. Magistrate Monica Borg Galea has launched an inquiry.
og_top_image_caption: The white Nissan March was involved in a collision with a motorbike in Birkirkara early on Friday morning. The car driver fled the scene and is still on the run. Photos: Malta Police Force

og_title: Over a day later, police still searching for driver who fled Birkirkara crash
og_subtitle: The Friday morning accident left a motorcyclist with serious injuries
og_content: Over 24 hours after a collision between a motorcycle and a car left a biker with serious injuries, police are still looking for the car driver who fled the scene of the accident. A 57-year-old man from Msida, who was riding a Honda motorbike, was involved in a collision with a Nissan March at 5.30am on Friday on Sir Anthony Mamo Street in Birkirkara. Police had said that a 25-year old woman, who is now understood to have been the passenger in the Nissan, was taken to hospital in a state of shock. She was otherwise uninjured. However, the male driver of the Nissan allegedly fled the scene of the accident. On Saturday afternoon, police confirmed they are still looking for the man as investigations into the accident continue. Magistrate Monica Borg Galea has launched an inquiry.
og_top_image_caption: The white Nissan March was involved in a collision with a motorbike in Birkirkara early on Friday morning. The car driver fled the scene and is still on the run. Photos: Malta Police Force

og_title: Labour MP Edward Zammit Lewis backs calls for random breath testing
og_subtitle: Former justice minister joins chorus of voices calling for measure to cut road deaths
og_content: Labour MP Edward Zammit Lewis has backed calls for the government to introduce random breath testing to reduce road deaths.  The former justice minister joined a growing list of individuals and organisations asking for police to be given the power to test drivers for drugs and alcohol, even if they do not show signs of inebriation.  "Random testing without the need for reasonable suspicion is an effective preventative tool,” Zammit Lewis said.   Pressure has been mounting on the government to introduce random breath testing over the past few weeks, following a spate of serious traffic accidents in which drugs and alcohol were involved.   Zammit Lewis said that the situation on the roads appeared to be worsening, while referring to repeated pleas to the authorities by emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin.    “This despite several projects by Labour governments to greatly improve our country’s infrastructure in an effort to increase safety, especially by my colleague Ian Borg,” he wrote on Facebook.  Zammit Lewis acknowledged that random testing presented an ethical dilemma when it came to protecting people’s right to privacy, but said he believed the proposed change to the law would benefit the common good by increasing road safety and saving lives.  “There are models in countries like the Netherlands, Sweden, France, Germany and Ireland, which have been implemented and are now seen as effective deterrent to fatal traffic accidents.”  The MP said he agreed with Prime Minister Robert Abela, who on Sunday said the government was reviewing drink-driving penalties.  “However, I also agree with the idea of ‘prevention not reaction’," he said. Both the Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association and the Association of Catering Establishments have backed calls for random testing, as has Insurance Association Malta.   The legal amendment has also found support among the judiciary. In a recent inquiry into the death of a motorcyclist who was found to have cocaine in his system, Magistrate Joe Mifsud endorsed a 2023 position paper co-written by NGO Doctors For Road Safety, the Maltese Association of Psychiatry and the Foundation for Welfare Services on drug-driving under the influence of psychoactive drugs.    Mifsud endorsed each of the paper’s eight recommendations, including the introduction of a legal framework to enable random drug testing for psychoactive substances, as well as the random screening of professional drivers, such as taxi, school bus, coach and heavy machinery drivers.  Zammit Lewis has recently used social media to take aim at various government measures.  He criticised the prime minister's planning reforms committee and pushed for the immediate recognition of the state of Palestine.
og_top_image_caption: Zammit Lewis said Malta should follow in the footsteps of various EU countries in introducing random breath tests on motorists. File photo.

og_title: Random drug, alcohol testing to be introduced; mandatory prison for fatalities
og_subtitle: Plan to introduce roadside tests and harshen punishment for drivers
og_content: The government is planning to introduce random drug and alcohol testing on the roads and to ensure anyone who kills someone under the influence cannot get a suspended sentence, but is sent to prison. Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the details of a new law that has been tabled in parliament in the wake of pressure from several professionals following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer. The proposed changes, which Camilleri said come as police road checks have surged to unprecedented levels, focus on strengthening penalties and introducing new testing methods. If the law is approved, police will be empowered to conduct drug tests on drivers at the roadside, similar to current alcohol checks. Drug and alcohol tests can be performed on drivers even without reasonable suspicion. Moreover, anyone who causes a person's death while under the influence of alcohol or drugs will face a mandatory prison sentence, eliminating the option of a suspended sentence. And fines for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs will be increased. Police will also be able to request the immediate suspension of a driver's license while court proceedings are pending. At present motorists are only tested after accidents or when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that they may be driving under the influence.  Emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin on Sunday reiterated his call for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs, saying it is the true deterrent in decreasing injury and death. Several groups have over the past weeks called for roadside random testing after a spate of accidents linked to driving under the influence. Among them were the Insurance Association, the Malta Hotels and Catering Establishments, the Association of Catering Establishments (ACE). The government itself raised the possibility of random drug testing for drivers when it launched the National Drug Policy for public consultation in March last year. The Nationalist Party had said it would bring in a private member's bill to try to reduce road deaths.
og_top_image_caption: At present motorists are only tested after accidents or when there is 'reasonable suspicion' that they may be driving under the influence. Photo: Shutterstock

og_title: Emergency doctor hails introduction of random drink-driving roadside tests
og_subtitle: "Reason prevails", emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin said after his repeated calls for random testing were finally heard
og_content: The emergency doctor who has been calling for random testing of motorists for alcohol and drugs praised the government’s decision to introduce such random tests.  “Reason prevails: Random roadside testing leads the way,” emergency doctor Jonathan Joslin said in a Facebook post on Tuesday, shortly after the government announced several proposals to curb drink-drug driving.  “The adoption of random roadside testing marks a decisive step towards safer roads. By deterring dangerous behaviours such as drink and drug driving, it ensures greater accountability among drivers and creates a stronger culture of responsibility on our roads,” Joslin said.  Joslin was at the forefront insisting that random testing would be a more effective deterrent to prevent serious traffic accidents than the reactive imposition of higher penalties to those who cause such crashes. His comments come after Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the proposed changes, in the wake of pressure from several professionals and lobby groups following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer.  They will be incorporated into a bill tabled in parliament last June, titled Traffic Regulation Ordinance (Amendment) Bill, which will be debated once parliament resumes in September. Only the bill's title was tabled at the time.  If the bill is approved, police will be empowered to conduct drug tests on drivers at the roadside, similar to current alcohol checks. Fines for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs will also be increased.  Moreover, anyone who causes a person's death while under the influence of alcohol or drugs will face a mandatory prison sentence, eliminating the option of a suspended sentence. Along with Joslin, the Insurance Association Malta also welcomed the government's move to introduce harsher penalties for drunk and drugged driving. The IAM said it has been actively lobbying for such measures over recent years, as it firmly believes tougher enforcement will serve as a much-needed deterrent against irresponsible and dangerous conduct on the roads. “These measures send a clear signal to all that protecting the lives of responsible, law-abiding road users is paramount,” IAM director General Adrian Galea said. The Association said the reform represents an important step forward in safeguarding lives.
og_top_image_caption: An AFM solider is being charged for driving under the influence in a fatal car crash last month. Photo: Malta Police Force

og_title: Roadside testing could create injustice for thousands of cannabis users: Releaf
og_subtitle: 'Presence of drugs in saliva does not mean impairment' - NGO
og_content: A cannabis association slammed the government's decision to introduce random roadside alcohol and drug testing, claiming it can create "injustice" for thousands of cannabis users.  While the decision to introduce tougher drink and drug laws was welcomed by the opposition and industry stakeholders, Releaf Malta didn't share the same sentiment.  "Releaf Malta has been requesting a meeting for six months, but we always find doors shut in our faces," Releaf Malta president Andrew Bonello said in a reel on Tuesday evening.  "The amendments introducing roadside testing for cannabis without an 'impairment assessment' will create injustice for over 60,000 cannabis users. We remind that the presence of drugs in saliva does not mean impairment or that the person is dangerous."  Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced the proposed changes on Tuesday, in the wake of pressure from several professionals and lobby groups following a spate of horrifying road accidents this summer. The proposed changes, which Camilleri said come as police road checks have surged to unprecedented levels, focus on strengthening penalties and introducing new testing methods. Camilleri did not clarify what drugs would be tested.  Bonello said cannabis can be detected hours after last use, but he argued it does not mean the person is dangerous and unable to drive.  He said breathalysers work differently and indicate when a driver is not in a fit state to drive. "Dialogue with us as you do with insurance companies and lawyers who have an economic interest in these measures passing. We remind that across Europe there are hundreds of court cases challenging unfair technologies like these," Bonello said. Malta became the first EU country to legalise recreational cannabis use in 2021. Under current legislation, adults are allowed to possess up to seven grams of cannabis and grow up to four plants at home. Consumption remains limited to private spaces and is prohibited in public or near minors.
og_top_image_caption: Releaf Malta disagrees with the introduction of random drug roadside testing, claiming it will create injustice for cannabis users. Photo: Shutterstock

og_title: Random roadside drugs and alcohol testing 'significant step forward'
og_subtitle: Measures 'essential' for Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination
og_content: The Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association on Wednesday “strongly supported” random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol saying it will have a positive impact on Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination. The association said the introduction of random roadside testing is a “significant step forward” in addressing reckless behaviour on the roads and protecting lives. “These measures are not only essential for upholding the rule of law but also for reinforcing Malta’s international reputation as a safe and welcoming destination,” the MHRA said. Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced on Tuesday announced that police will be given the power to randomly test drivers for alcohol or drugs while laws will be revised to ensure anyone involved in fatal crashes while driving under the influence is sent to prison.   Recognising that safety and security are “decisive success factors” for Malta as a “quality tourism destination”, the MHRA said tourists and residents must feel assured that Malta provides a safe and orderly environment, free from risks that undermine wellbeing and public trust. The association stressed that better sustainable tourism management is “inseparable” from responsible enforcement and strong deterrents against behaviour that endanger society. “These reforms will help ensure a higher standard of living for residents and the local community, while delivering outstanding, safe experiences for even the most discerning tourists,” the MHRA added.
og_top_image_caption: The MHRA says it "strongly supports" the introduction of random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol as it will make Malta safer not just for residents for also for tourists. File photo: Shutterstock

og_title: Man killed by electric shock identified as Charles Mifsud
og_subtitle: Former hawker remembered by Żebbuġ residents as a ‘true gentleman’
og_content: A man who died by electric shock on Wednesday near Golden Bay has been identified as Charles Mifsud. Mifsud, 41, was a resident of Żebbuġ. He died after being electrocuted while working on an electricity pole, falling into a ditch as a result of the accident. It remains unclear what Mifsud was working on at the time of his death. It is also not yet known whether he was self-employed or working for a company. Until a few years ago, he was a fruit and vegetable vendor in Żebbuġ and was well-known in the community. Residents of Żebbuġ took to social media on Thursday to express their "shock" and condolences, with people stating that he was a "true gentleman”. The accident occurred at around 12.30pm on Wednesday in Triq Palma, near Golden Bay. He was assisted by rescuers from the Civil Protection Department and an ambulance crew but died later in hospital. Magistrate Joe Mifsud is leading an inquiry. Police and the Occupational Health and Safety Authority are investigating. Four people died in workplace accidents during the first six months of the year, while 1,041 non-fatal accidents were recorded, according to data released by the National Statistics Office.
og_top_image_caption: Charles Mifsud and his wife. Photo: Facebook.

og_title: No entry sign put up at Mġiebaħ Bay as danger looms right on top of bathers
og_subtitle: The sign was put up hours after Times of Malta queried the lack of safety measures in place
og_content: The Public Works authorities on Tuesday evening placed a ‘Danger no entry’ warning sign at Mġiebaħ Bay, hours after Times of Malta queried a lack of safety measures in place and four months after a government report identified unstable rock formations as a “significant risk to public safety”.  The report had said that action should be taken “as soon as possible to prevent any avoidable incidents”.  It remains unclear whether any further safety measures will follow the placement of the no-entry sign. Mġiebaħ Bay, in Mellieħa’s Selmun area, is a swimming spot favoured by those wanting to avoid crowds. Pictures posted on social media and others taken by Times of Malta show deep cracks in rock formations just above a flat, clay part of Mġiebaħ that is popular with bathers.  Frenki Dragan Crnjakovic, who flagged the issue on the Facebook group ‘The BEST of Malta’, said he highlighted the issue last year. “A huge chunk of rock is waiting for its moment to crash into the sea. I wrote about this last year but it seems my post didn’t reach many people. Be kind – share with your friends. I believe that it will also reach the official services that will mark or fence off these dangerous areas,” he said.  Mellieħa mayor Gabriel Micallef said he first reported the issue to the police and several government entities last April. He pointed to a particular rock formation that seemed close to dislodging onto the crowd. By May, a report commissioned by the police and drawn up by the Public Works Department’s Project Design and Engineering Directorate confirmed the danger. “It has been observed that large boulders are gradually becoming dislodged due to ongoing coastal erosion,” the report, dated May 9, says. “This natural process is giving rise to areas that pose a significant risk to public safety, especially as the summer season approaches and the bay is expected to attract a high number of visitors for sunbathing and swimming,” it says. The report said that, besides the cracks in the rock formation highlighted by Micallef, other rock formations in other parts of the bay were dangerous. “In view of the above, I strongly recommend that a qualified geotechnical engineer be urgently commissioned to carry out a comprehensive assessment of the site. The objective of this evaluation should be to identify zones of potential danger and advise on any necessary mitigation measures,” the report says. “Given the imminent increase in public use of this location, this assessment should be undertaken as soon as possible to prevent any avoidable incidents.” Correspondence provided to Times of Malta by the Mellieħa mayor shows that the Lands Authority was alerted to the problem. Micallef said that the last communication he had from the authority was in June, when the Lands Authority and the council agreed to install danger signs. “Kindly note that danger signs have been ordered and I will update you with the date of installation,” the e-mail, dated June 24, said. Questions have been sent to the lands ministry. Last year, 22-year-old Mirabelle Falzon died when she was hit by falling rocks at a popular spot in an area known as Munxar, in the limits of St Thomas Bay. The ruins of an 18th-century military battery, known as Riħama, are perched on the cliff overlooking the site. After the incident, several signs were put up, warning that swimming in the area is prohibited, and a fence was erected around the battery itself.  A magisterial inquiry into the tragedy said reports about the dangerous state of the coastal battery in Marsascala, made in the months and years before the collapse killed Falzon, were lost in the bureaucracy of government entities.  The magistrate recommended that a single entity should be responsible for receiving reports about state-owned and private buildings, as well as abandoned buildings and structures like bastions and cliffs that presented a danger to the public. In a statement reacting to the conclusions, the government said it will be implementing the court’s recommendation for there to be one entity “that will receive reports about government buildings or private buildings, as well as about walls, cliffs, or abandoned buildings that pose a danger to the public”.
og_top_image_caption: The site at risk of a potentially deadly rockfall. (Chris Sant Fournier)

og_title: 23 crashes, 10 breakdowns and two spillages: Tuesday sees extra bad traffic
og_subtitle: It remains unclear whether the traffic jams were linked to the high number of accidents.
og_content: Traffic congestion and gridlocks were particularly bad on Tuesday, a day that also registered an abnormally high number of accidents. Motorists reported spending more than double the usual time on their commutes on Tuesday, and many took to social media to express frustration, complaining about standstill traffic that stretched even onto non-arterial roads. In a Facebook post, Transport Malta said there were 23 collisions, 10 vehicle breakdowns and two separate spillages across the island on Tuesday. It said calls for assistance were more numerous than other days, and its officers were much busier trying to solve the gridlocks. And those are just the cases Transport Malta assisted in, and do not include accidents that were reported to LESA. However, it is unclear whether the traffic jams were linked to the high number of accidents.  Transport Malta constantly monitors the roads using scores of cameras scattered around the island, and it employs officers on foot, motorbikes and in cars to patrol and clear the roads whenever accidents occur. To ensure roads are cleared as quickly as possible, officers - and sometimes whole units - are immediately deployed to the scene of a crash or breakdown, or when heavy vehicles spill hazardous fluids, materials, or chemicals. Traffic frustration On Tuesday, several motorists on social media said a journey from Sliema to Marsa took up to 1.5 hours, the short hop from Ta' Xbiex to Msida was an hour-long ordeal, the route from San Ġwann to Msida lasted 45 minutes, and drivers travelling from the Three Cities to Attard spent 1.5 hours stuck in traffic.  Key hotspots throughout the day included the St. Paul’s Bay bypass, with heavy congestion along the Coast Road and in St Julian's. Furthermore, traffic was especially bad in Paola, Marsa's Aldo Moro Road, the Marsa/Ħamrun bypass and Regional Road. Major traffic was also reported on most roads leading in and out of the Gżira, Ta’ Xbiex, and Msida area, with vehicles barely moving. Parliament drama The day's traffic woes even spilled into an impromptu banter session in parliament later that day between Prime Minister Robert Abela and Opposition Leader Alex Borg. The drama began when government whip Naomi Cachia accused the opposition of raising a procedural issue simply to buy time for Borg to arrive, as he was running late. Borg eventually arrived mid-way through Abela’s speech. When he took the floor, he told the Prime Minister he was delayed because, unlike Abela, he was stuck in traffic as he doesn't have an escort. Abela quickly hit back, telling Borg he "better had his licence and insurance paid". This was a reference to a recent incident involving Borg's partner, Sarah Bajada, who was caught driving without a valid vehicle licence and insurance.
og_top_image_caption: Traffic was especially bad on Tuesday. File photo

og_title: Today's front pages
og_subtitle: The top stories in Malta's newspapers
og_content: The following are the top stories in Malta's newspapers on Monday. Times of Malta leads with survey data showing that traffic, parking and public transport-related issues are now Malta’s biggest headache, and by a large margin. It also reports that a mother of two boys aged seven and nine, who wished there was a way she could avoid giving them a smartphone until they were old enough to handle its perils, has created a group of parents who agreed to keep them off their devices. The Malta Independent meanwhile, publishes comments by the Pyrotechnic Association that the PN environment bill could have been reasonable but was vague.  In-Nazzjon reports that a PN fundraiser on Sunday raised €508,225 in donations by party supporters.  It also publishes comments by PN leader Alex Borg that the party should continue believing it was capable of returning to government.  L-orizzont publishes comments by prime minister Robert Abela, who on Sunday told party supporters that traditions will be safeguarded by the constitution.
og_top_image_caption: File photo: Times of Malta
